Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS: Collaborative Research: A 21st Century Reconnaissance of Aleutian Arc Inception
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Alaska/Aleutian Arc is the most geologically active region in North America with abundant large earthquakes and eruptions from more than 50 active volcanoes. Determining precisely how and when the Aleutian Arc began to form is one of the key elements for understanding the origin of the Bering Sea-Alaska-North Pacific region as well as how several circum-Pacific volcanic zones are related to one another. Our understanding of how volcanism initiated in the Aleutian Arc is clouded due in large part to the scarcity of data that bear on the ages of the earliest volcanic rocks in the Aleutian Islands. The proposed reconnaissance investigation of Aleutian Arc inception involves sampling and determining the ages of the oldest records of volcanism. The aim is to define when Aleutian arc volcanism started and highlight potential linkages with the initiation of volcanism elsewhere in the Pacific and the rapid change in the relative motions of oceanic plates that occurred 52 million years ago. In addition, the proposed research will generate basic information regarding how and why the Aleutian arc poses significant volcanic and earthquake hazards to the population in Alaska and around the Pacific Rim.

The proposed research will employ state-of-the-art 40Ar/39Ar and U-Pb geochronology, along with geochemical, and isotopic analysis of the dated rocks. The focus is on subaerial outcrops on Amatignak, Ulak, and Kiska islands, which hold the greatest potential for exploration into the early history of the Aleutians. New geochronologic and geochemical data will precisely constrain when the Aleutian arc inception began, what the compositions of the eruptive products were, and how they evolved through the earliest history of the arc. This information will also be used to evaluate the existing tectonic models of Aleutian arc inception and Pacific Plate motion during the middle Eocene. This project will forge a new collaboration between scientists at UW-Madison, Cornell University, and the University of Alaska-Fairbanks/USGS that may benefit the GeoPRISMS program for its duration. Our findings will be used immediately to determine where future efforts to examine the Aleutian Arc and its fore-arc structures via submersible ROVs, dredging, and geophysical imaging should concentrate to best address questions of subduction zone initiation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Earth's plate tectonic engine is powered by subduction of oceanic lithosphere, yet we know little of how subduction zones begin and operate in their early stages and how their physical, chemical and petrologic processes combine to generate new continental crust.  One of the most important and longest subducton zones is the volcanically active and earthquake prone Aleutian arc in Alaska, whose oceanic segment runs for more than a 1000 miles from the end of the Alaska Pennisula to west of Attu Island in the USA and on into Russia.  Determining how, when and why the Aleutian Arc began to form is crucial to deciphering the plate tectonic puzze of the Berring Sea-Alaska-North Pacific region and to a possible linkage to the formation of western Pacific arcs.  In NSF, the origin and development of the Aleutian arc is a critical issie in the GeoPRISMS program.

A limiting factor in understanding the origin and early evolution of the arc has been a paucity of radioisotopic ages and geochemical and isotopic data from poorly exposed older arc rocks, many of which are under water.  To attack this problem, we generated new Ar/Ar and U-Pb geochronlogy and geochemical data from the oldest sequences in the central and western arc and the forearc islands closest to the Aleutian Trench.  As expected, the results are in accord with the arc initiating at ~55-50 Ma in response to  Pacific plate re-organization associated with the demise of the Resurrection Plate and near the time that the western Pacific Izu-Bonin-Mariana arc system intiated.  In this study, we showed that Attu Island in the western part of the Aleutian arc was operating as a Marianas style arc-backarc pair by 42 Ma, had a substantial plutonic component from 35-30 Ma, was behaving more like the central Aleutians at 7-5 Ma and reached its current oblique configuration after 5 Ma.  The oldest arc rocks on Kiska Island to the east show similiarites.  In contrast, we found no evidence for Marianas style arc/backarc style magmatism on the islands to the east of where the Bowers ridge joins the Aleutian arc.  The oldest age obtainined in this region was a near the limit of detection ~48 Ma Ar/Ar plagioclase age from a granulite xenolith that originated as a gabbroic arc cumulate and reached the sufrace in a Kanaga Island basalt flow.  The oldest rocks (~38 Ma) found in this central Aleutian region are Eocene mafic volcanic rocks whose magma sources are generally similar to those of modern central Aleutian arc rocks.  These Eocene rocks were in turn intruded by continental-like calc-akaline plutons with ages from 35-13 Ma, whose amphibole compositions suggest that they intruded into a crust that was ~ 35 km or more in thickness by 35 Ma.  A subsequent progressive northward shift in the magmatic front in this part of the arc is interpreted to be the consequence of the removal of forearc crust by subduction erosion with the removed crust entering and being recyled through the mantle wedge.

Broader Impacts

Understanding the origin and subsequent evolution of the Aleutian Arc is critical as its high frequency of Mw 8 or greater earthquakes and greater than VEI 4 volcanic eruptions poses significant hazards to Alaska and the surrounding region.  The frequent volcanic eruptions have the potential to disturb economically vital north Pacific air traffic, and the earthquakes and massive submarine debris avalanches are capable of generating tsunamis in Alaska and around the Pacific basin.  The research in this project has generated basic information on how the Aleutian Arc has evolved and behaves today and why it poses such threats.  The advances in this project particularly elucidate a better understanding of the initial and early stages of the formation of the subduction zone and thus contribute to understanding the origin and evolution of the faults that generate the earthquakes and the subducting slab that generates the volcanic eruptions.

On a different front, this project has forged collaborations between UW-Madison and Cornell University scientists that merge their complementary research capabilities and link their long-term research effors in the Aleutians.  The findings in this study are also valuable in directing new and ongoing research efforts in the Aleutians particularly those involving submersible ROVs, dredging and geophysical imaging.  Finally, this project has led to a MS thesis for a UW-Madison student, a pending PhD thesis for a female Cornell student and laboratory research experiences and projects for undergraduates.  Materials from this study have been incorporated into new laboratory exercises in the Cornell earth science curriculum.
